Photoresponsive DNA nanomaterials represent a new class of remarkable functional materials. By adjusting the irradiation wavelength, light intensity, and exposure time, various photocontrolled DNA-based systems can be reversibly or irreversibly regulated in respect of their size, shape, conformation, movement, and dissociation/association. This Review introduces the most updated progress in the development of photoresponsive DNA-based system and emphasizes their advantages over other stimuli-responsive systems. Their design and mechanisms to trigger the photoresponses are shown and discussed. The potential application of these photon-responsive DNA nanomaterials in biology, biomedicine, materials science, nanophotonic and nanoelectronic are also covered and described. The challenges faced and further directions of the development of photocontrolled DNA-based systems are also highlighted.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
DNA has been emerging as an extremely powerful and versatile scaffold for nanoscale construction due to its specific molecular recognition property, controllable nucleobase sequence, its ease of synthesis and chemical modification and stimuli-triggered responsiveness.[1] High programmability and predictability of oligonucleotides have instigated the rapid development in the field of 2D and 3D DNA self-assembly for potential applications in materials science, biology, physics, and engineering.[2–5] In fact, the base sequences of oligonucleotide, for example, cytosine-rich DNA, guanosine-rich DNA, and aptamers encode valuable functional and structural information, being favorable for the rational design of stimuli-responsive DNA nanomaterials.[6–8] In the past years, a large number of static and dynamic self-assembled DNA nanostructures have been successfully designed and synthesized via different self-assembly strategies. Particularly, their stimuli-triggered

It could possibly damage the whole biological system could possibly be damaged if the intracellular temperature is too high or too low as well thermal shock. To overcome these problems, light is highly attractive as a triggering modality.
Light is noninvasive, allowing instantaneous manipulation and remotely triggering of the systems with high spatiotemporal precision and accuracy.[25] This would result in eliminating the steric hindrance effect of the action sites of bulky DNA nanostructures. Though sometimes high energy light irradiation may decompose the DNA strands or generate heat to destabilize the DNA system, parameters including light power, wavelength, and exposure time can be adjusted to control the performance of these photon-responsive platforms. Additionally, it is a clean source while no waste is accumulated to hamper its performance as compared to other stimuli-responsive DNA system. Sometimes the only waste produced would be just the short DNA fragments cleaved by light stimuli. However, it will not be a big problem as long as the light can penetrate through the whole system. Moreover, if the DNA device is designed to work in in vitro system, the unwanted DNA could be degraded by nuclease and eliminated in biological system. To develop photoactivated DNA nanomaterials, photosensitive groups such as photoisomerizable molecules, photon-cleavable molecules, photon-caging molecules, or photopolymerizable molecules have to be introduced into the DNA system.[26] They would lead to either 1) reversibly switch the DNA assembly between two different states; 2) irreversibly break DNA assembly into at least two pieces, 3) irreversibly remove the photo-protection group on the nucleobases or 4) polymerize the DNA monomers into a larger assemblies upon light irradiation.
This review will introduce the most updated progress in the development of photoresponsive system based on self-assembled DNA nanostructures and emphasize their advantages over other stimuli-responsive systems. The working mechanisms of several chemical approaches including photodecaging, photocleavage, photoisomerization, and photopolymerization to regulate oligonucleotide hybridization with different wavelengths of light will be shown and discussed. Representative examples of the lighttriggered responses including molecular switching, conformational change, assembly and disassembly, and motion induction will also be briefly described. The potential application of these photon-responsive DNA nanomaterials in biology, biomedicine, materials science, nanophotonic, and nanoelectronic will be covered and discussed. This review article also highlights the challenges faced and further directions of the development of photocontrolled DNA-based systems.

sections.heading: 2.1. By UV–Visible Induced Photocaging/Photocleavage
sections.text:
UV is a commonly used light source for photochemical reactions due to its high energy power and penetration. The wavelength range of UV light is from 10 to 400 nm. For DNA functionalization, 300–450 nm including the visible region are usually used because the maximum absorption wavelength of DNA is 260 nm.[27] Unfortunately, DNA would still be damaged under prolonged exposure and high power. The most widely used approach to regulate the DNA hybridization is to insert the photocleavable linkers such as ortho-nitrobenzyl (ONB) and bromohydroxyquinoline groups into the backbone of peptide nucleic acids (PNAs),[28] miRNA,[29] morpholino,[30,31] and DNA.[32] They have been used for photoregulation in oligonucleotides. Under UV light irradiation, the oligonucleotide is cleaved into two pieces by bond breaking of the incorporated photocleavable molecules, resulting in restoration of its functions (Figure 1A).[33] To design the activation of oligomer function, the functional DNA strand should firstly be tethered by a partially complementary DNA inhibitor via covalent linkage of photocleavable linker. The complementary duplex is inactive in the absence of light irradiation. Upon UV light irradiation, the photoactive molecule is cleaved and thus the functional strand is released freely for further actions (Figure 1B).[34] Different parameters such as the sequence design and the minimum number of the nucleotides in each strand are highly considered for feasible photoswitching between their On and OFF states. To address these limitations, circular oligonucleotide incorporated with a photocleavable moiety was applied. In the absence of light irradiation, this circular oligonucleotide showed very limited flexibility in its structure for binding to its complementary target strand. It will be opened and become active for hybridization after photolysis of the photocleavable moiety. Therefore, this approach is highly suitable for antisense applications.[35,36]
Another approach to trigger the oligonucleotide functions is to incorporate the caging moieties on nucleobases (Figure 2).[37–44] Caged nucleotides can simply inhibit the Watson-Crick hydrogen bonding between the two complementary strands but the photolabile caging groups are removed and its decaging oligonucleotide is then active for duplex formation after photolysis (Figure 1C).[45] Additionally, the deactivation of photocaged nucleobases was achieved by decaging the complementary strand and thus a hairpin was formed to inhibit the activity of the target oligonucleotide after UV light irradiation (Figure 1D).[46] Friedman’s group has also produced an antisense strand incorporated with a photocaged nucleic acid.[47] The caging moieties acted as an obstacle for the enzyme action. Once UV irradiation was applied, the DNA strand will not be broken into two pieces but only the caging moieties leave. These allowed the antisense oligonucleotides exposed to the action enzyme for RNA interference (Figure 1E).

sections.heading: 2.2. By Photoisomerization
sections.text:
An alternative approach is to reversibly control the oligonucleotides hybridization via photoisomerization process. There are several commonly used photoisomerizable molecules including
stilbene,[48] spiropyran,[49] diarylethene,[50,51] and azobenzene derivatives for photon engines (Figure 3).[52] Stilbene reversibly isomerizes between cis- and trans-form upon UV light irradiation. This molecule was first reported by Lewis and Liu to photoregulate the mechanical motion of stilbene-modified DNA.[48] However, significant amount of space is required for its photoisomerization because rotation of the benzene ring is involved by breaking the CC π bond and then rotating the CC σ bond.[53] It is confirmed that photoisomerization of stilbene would not happen when it is intercalated in a double-stranded DNA.[54] Upon UV light irradiation (e.g., 300–400 nm), spiroyran was switched from a closed, nonplanar form into an open, planar merocyanine form with highly π-conjugated system. Afterward, merocyanine can easily convert back to spiroyran by visible light irradiation (λ > 490 nm).[55] It is highly limited to use in aqueous medium because of the hydrophilic feature of its zwitterionic structure. Moreover, diarylethene undergoes reversibly closed-to-open and open-to-closed isomerization in response to visible and UV light irradiation respectively.[56] Due to its limited conformational change, diarylethene may not offer enough mechanical power to stimulate a motion.
Among a number of photoisomerizable molecules, azobenzene and its derivatives are the most popular phototrigger for versatile applications because of: 1) simple chemical synthesis; 2) high chemical stability between repeated trans- and cisphotoisomerization in aqueous conditions; 3) high feasibility of the conformational change in a densely packed DNA system. By looking at the chemical structure of azobenzene, it contains a NN double bond, which connects the two phenyl moieties in specific configuration (Figure 4).[57] When azobenzene molecules were intercalated at specific positions on DNA duplex, its helical binding stability could be easily disturbed by the polarity and conformational change of azobenzene under sequential irradiation of UV and visible light. It is experimentally confirmed that the overall binding stability of a DNA duplex is uniformly increased with increasing the number of trans-form azobenzene inserted.[58–60] Upon UV light irradiation, trans-tocis conversion of azobenzene whose biphenyl groups are on the same side of NN bond and form a nonplanar structure, disturbs the π–π stacking of nucleobase and destabilize the duplex formation. To reform the duplex DNA, visible light (λ > 400 nm) is applied to foster cis-to-trans conversion of azobenzene back to its planar structure. In general, no side reaction happens in photoisomerization of azobenzene.[58,59] The kinetics has also been studied that trans to cis isomerization was ≈107 times slower than the reversed process.[61] Other than the commercially available azobenzene phosphoramidite which could be incorporated into DNA strand through solid-phase synthesis, Tan’s group also developed a phosphoramidite made by combination of azobenzene with a natural thymine base, allowing hybridization with normal base at the trans form.[62] Asunuma’s group firstly designed a simple DNA tweezer which composed of three natural DNA strands (W, X, and Y) and one azobenzene-modified DNA strand (Z) (Figure 5).[63] Upon visible light irradiation (e.g., 440–460 nm), all strands came together to form stable and rigid DNA duplexes with two arms sticking out while the quencher and fluorophore on strand W were in close proximity, causing quenching effect of the tetrachlorofluorescein. sections.heading: 2.3. By Photoinduced Polymerization
sections.text:
Acrydite is an acrylic phosphoramidite, which is used to modify the oligonucleotide with methacryl groups at both terminals. These methacryl groups could further polymerize into polymer structures under UV light irradiation. This is highly attributed to the formation of CC single bond linked between all monomers. Taking the advantages of photopolymerization property of acrydite, Tan’s and Luo’s group conducted extensive research on the creation of acrydite-modified, branched, and cross-linkable DNA building blocks to generate highly ordered, polymeric DNA nanostructures with multifunctional moieties in a photocontrolled manner (Figure 6).[65,66] For example, they designed to generate a number of Y-shaped DNA domains functionalized with quantum dots, targeting aptamers, anticancer drugs, therapeutic antisense oligonucleotides and built-in photoreactive groups at the edges. These functional DNA domains were then connected to an X-shaped DNA linker through hybridization of complementary DNA strands in the edges of Y-shaped functional domains and X-shaped linker. Other than acrydite, an ultrafast inter-strand photocrosslinking reaction with the use of 3-cyanovinylcarbazole nucleoside (CNVK) in duplex DNA has been developed.[67] In the presence of UV light excitation at 366 nm for 1 s, the CNVK can photocrosslink with the adjacent thymine base while the entire process could be reversed in response to UV irradiation at 312 nm for 60 s. With these careful designs of DNA strands, reversible polymerization would be highly possible. The details of these example would be illustrated in Section 3.3.

sections.heading: 2.4. By Near Infrared-Mediated Photocleavage
sections.text:
The above photoresponsive molecules are highly relied on UV irradiation of ≈360 nm for efficient isomerization or decaging. The drawbacks of using UV light as stimulus include poor tissue penetration, high photodamage, and low precision focusing of the excitation process. To overcome these obstacles, a two-photon excitation has considered as an alternative.[70] Typically, two-photon caging molecules that exhibit an absorption maximum at above 350 nm can be excited by light at nearIR or IR wavelengths (e.g., ≈700–1000 nm). The key feature of a good two-photon removable group should show a high value of uncaging cross-section δu, which is the product of a twophoton uncaging quantum yield Qu and a two-photon absorbance cross section δa.[71] Unfortunately, most of the existing one-photon removable groups exhibited poor efficiency in two-photon excitation.[72] Typically, the dipolar characteristic of linear two-photon absorption (TPA) chromophores is basically composed of two electron-acceptor (A) or electron-donor (D) moieties covalently connected with a central core by fully conjugated system (Figure 7A).[73] Their TPA properties can be simply improved by extending the π-conjugation system and/or enhancing the electron-withdrawing or-donating ability of these side groups. Efforts have been put on the chemical modification of these existing one-photon active molecules such as o-nitrobenzyl to enhance their two-photon sensitivity
and the development of new chromophores for highly efficient two-photon decaging.[74–76] In the molecular design, optimization of the TPA property for organic molecules was a key point. In the past decades, several groups have successfully designed and synthesized a series of efficient two-photon cleavable molecules including 3-(2-propyl)-4′-methoxy-4-nitrobiphenyl (PMNB), aqueous soluble (2,7-bis-{4-nitro-8-[3-(2propyl)-styryl]}-9.9-bis-[1-(3,6-dioxaheptyl)]-fluorene (BNSF), and quadrupolar (4,4′-bis-{8-[4-nitro-3-(2-propyl)-styryl]}-3,3′dimethoxybiphenyl (BNSMB) (Figure 7B).[73] Additionally, Matsuba’s group has synthesized 6-bromo-7-hydroxycoumarin4-methyl (Bhc) caging nucleosides via a carbamate linkage of Bhc group at the N6 position of deoxyadenosine and the N4 position of deoxycytidine (Figure 8A).[77] Lusic et al. subsequently reported the use of 3-nitro-2-ehtyldibenzofuran (NDBF) caging group on a thymidine phosphoramidite for efficient two-photon cleavable process (Figure 8B).[78] These moieties are suitable for standard DNA synthesis on an automated DNA synthesizer via standard cyanoethylphosphoramidite chemistry. Thus, this would allow us to synthesize a series of two-photon-controlled oligonucleotides for various biological applications.
Among these different light-triggered approaches of DNA regulation, only photoisomerization and photocrosslinking with 3-cyanovinylcarbazole nucleoside analogues are reversible.

sections.heading: 3. Working Principle of Self-Assembled DNA Nanomaterials in Response to Light
sections.text: In response to the light stimuli, the DNA-based nanosystem was simply converted the photon energy into kinetic energy by either bond breaking, bond formation or reversible molecular isomerization. These would result in a number of phototriggered responses such as size and shapes alteration, conformation change, aggregation and disaggregation, and movement induction.

When the azo molecules were in their trans form, these two sticky ends overhangs hybridized with each other, giving rise to an “X” shape inside the cavity. When the UV light was irradiated, the azo molecules turned to the nonplanar cis form. This resulted in the dissociation of the duplex DNA linker and restoration of the two pairs of duplex DNA strands in a parallel manner inside the cavity (Figure 9A). The switching of the two pairs of duplex DNA strands between “X” shape and parallel arrangements was fully reversible and clearly visualized by liquid AFM imaging. Subsequently, the same group also used the similar DNA origami structures to generate dual switch in response to photoirradiation and addition of potassium ions.[80] Endo’s group have also made a photoregulated DNA-based rotary system with similar approach.[81]
Alternatively, the overall volume of the nanosystem could also be regulated by photocontrolled DNA assembly. Tan’s group has successfully fabricated a photoswitchable dynamic hydrogel using doubled-stranded DNAs as photoreversible cross-linkers (Figure 9B). This hydrogel was formed by grafting two kinds of polyacrylamide chains, which were modified with both regular DNA with acrydite or azo-incorporated DNA strand with acrydite.[82] The two complementary DNA strands were first hybridized together under visible light, resulting in a compressed form and decreased volume. When the photoswitchable polyacrylamide was shined under UV light, the
trans-azo would isomerize to cis form and destabilize the DNA hybridization. The DNA strands were then relaxed with extra spaces. This leaded to the increase of the overall volume of the hydrogel. Repeated UV and visible light irradiation, the dynamic hydrogels became swelling and shrinking reversibly up to eight cycles. With this new technique, light-responsive dynamic DNA-based hydrogel could be used to fabricate various light-controlled actuators which simply converted light energy into a macroscopic volume change for a number of applications.

sections.heading: 3.2. Conformation Change
sections.text:
The first example of photoresponsive 3D DNA nanostructures was reported by Tan’s group in 2011.[83] They assembled an azofunctionalized DNA tetrahedron composed of four designed oligonucleotide sequences. Under UV light irradiation, the azo molecules arranged in every two nucleotides in a 17-mer DNA strand (Azo-17) were in their cis form, which hindered the hybridization with its complementary DNA strand in the selfassembled DNA tetrahedron, resulting in a contracted form of 3D structures with hairpins stacking out. Upon irradiation by visible light, the azo molecules changed to coplanar trans form and then allowed to bind to the hairpin region to further extend the distance of one side of the DNA tetrahedron. Sequential irradiation of UV and visible light would confer the reversible contract and expansion of tetrahedron (Figure 10A). Subsequently, Yang’s group and Endo’s group also demonstrated the operation of photoreversible DNA scissors in their close and open states in response to UV and visible light irradiations.[84,85]
More recently, Han’s group applied ortho-nitrobenzyl moiety to construct DNA origami sphere with configurational changes in response to UV lights.[86] They first assembled a hollow DNA origami sphere, which composed of two hemispheres closed by nitrobenzyl-functionalized sticky end in right-handed side. In the left-handed side, the two hemispheres were permanently linked by a single-stranded DNA. In response to UV irradiation, the nitrobenzyl molecules were photocleaved such that the double-stranded linker was dissociated. The entire closed DNA sphere was then immediately opened. This structural change could be easily observed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy.
Recently, our group also successfully developed some reversible and irreversible photon-cleavable 3D DNA nanotubes. First, we incorporated two-photon cleavable molecules, namely 4-nitro-4′-phenoxy-1,1′-biphenyl (4-NB), as one of the construction elements to the three edges along the 3D DNA nanotubes.[87] We found that linear and rigid nanotubes would become flexible nanostructures with bending features after irradiating of near infrared-red (NIR) light. This was attributed to the photocleavage of a single carbon–carbon bond of 4-NB along the three edges of the tube, leading to opening of its cavities and becoming partially single-stranded tubular structure (Figure 10B). Unfortunately, this photoactive system is irreversible, which means this DNA system could only be switched from close to open state by bond breaking. Subsequently, photoisomerizable azobenzene molecules were integrated as building blocks along the nanotubes to regulate its open–close process. In response to sequential

sections.heading: 3.3. Assembly and Disassembly
sections.text:
Sugiyama’s group utilized the azobenzene-modified hexagonal DNA origami monomers to construct different 2D DNA oligomers in both regular and irregular patterns. Their association and dissociation could be reversibly controlled by alternating irradiation of UV and visible lights (Figure 11A).[89] In this work, two DNA origami structures were functionalized with complementary overhangs consisting of three azo in one side. In response to the visible irradiation, the planar trans conformation of azo molecules would allow the two complementary overhangs from two different hexagonal DNA origami frames to hybridize and bind in an interstrand-wedge manner. This duplex linker would be disrupted and dimer structures would dissociate and turn back to their monomeric state when UV light is irradiated to the system. By adjusting the position of the azo-modified overhangs in the individual hexagonal-shaped DNA origami units, construction of nanostructures with diverse orientational patterns including linear, zig-zag, and ring-shaped is highly achievable. This kind of dynamic assembly and disassembly action of the photoresponsive DNA origami structures could be directly observed on a substrate with sphingomyelin-enriched domain of a mica supported lipid bilayer.[90] Tanaka et al. also reported the formation of photocontrollable DNA nanocapsule. This property triggered permanent memories and self-healing processes. These two functions demonstrate the potential of DNA hydrogel as photon-triggered shape-memory and self-healing materials for drug delivery and sensing.[93]

sections.heading: 3.4. Induction of Motion
sections.text: Famulok’s group has successfully generated a reversible, lightinduced DNA-based rotaxane, which consisted of two spherical DNA stoppers at both ends of a DNA duplex, one cyclic DNA ring and a 12-mer azobenzene-functionalized DNA strand (S-azo-DNA).[95] This system existed in two states: immobile DNA-pseudorotaxane state and a random DNA-rotaxane state. In the immobile state, the DNA ring was fixed along the axis DNA because eight nucleobases of the macrocycle ring were complementary to the arm of the axis DNA. Under the visible light irradiation, azobenzene molecules in this 12-mer S-azoDNA was switched from cis to trans form such that S-azo-DNA could fully bind to the arm and displace the DNA ring out. This resulted in free movement of the DNA ring along the axis DNA. Subsequently, the azobenzene molecules in the 12-mer S-azo-DNA would take cis form when UV light is applied. The S-azo-DNA would be dissociated from the arm and allow the macrocycle DNA ring bind back to the arm region (Figure 11B). The entire movement of the DNA ring along the DNA rotaxane was reversibly controlled by sequential UV and visible light irradiations. To control movement of DNA system, Endo’s group also made a DNA walker operated by 350 nm wavelength irradiation to cleave the disulfide bond.[96]

sections.heading: 4.1. Molecular Switch
sections.text:
Initially, Asanuma’a group reported a photoswitch made of two complementary DNA strands functionalized with azo molecules.[64] Different number of azo, different insertion position and different ratio between azo and nucleotides were also examined and optimized. They found that the design of one azo for every two nucleobases provides the highest stability of duplex in trans form. This is highly attributed to the multiple insertions of nonnatural nucleotides into both DNA strands. In this study, they confirmed that the reversible photoregulation of duplex formation (ON state) and duplex dissociation (OFF state) in the presence of UV and visible light irradiation. Subsequently, Zhang’s group also applied similar idea to fabricate a lightdriven switch composed of a single DNA strand (Figure 12A).[97] This strand designed to consist of hairpin-loop in the middle part, three photoisomerizable azo molecules incorporated into the duplex stem region and one fluorophore and one quencher at both ends. At the closed state or under visible light irradiation, the azo molecules were in trans form to hybridize with its complementary region on DNA strand. This gave rise to the close proximity of the fluorophore and quencher, resulting in
very weak fluorescence signal. Upon UV light irradiation, the cis form of azo destabilize the duplex formation such that the DNA strand was in its open state. This would give rise to a very strong fluorescence due to the long distance between the fluorophore and quencher in the relaxed state. This photoswitching process can be repeated up to seven cycles.
Stephanopoulos’ group recently constructed a reconfigurable DNA tweezer, which could be switched from a close state to an open state in response to UV light irradiation (Figure 12B).[98] The tweezer was made of two double-crossover tiles linked with a single-stranded poly A as hairpin loop. Another trigger poly T DNA that was protected with 6-nitropoperonyloxymethyl (NPOM) photocaging groups was incorporated into the nanostructure to prevent its hybridization with hairpin loop. Initially, the bundles of double helices were in a parallel manner. Once the UV light was applied, the photocaging groups were removed and then the trigger DNA hybridized to the hairpin loop. This resulted in opening of the DNA tweezer and the distance between its Cy-labeled arms was increased from 4 to 18 nm. This photocontrolled opening of DNA structure could potentially be used as a switch. In this study, direct photocaging of the designed displacement DNA strand would provide a novel mechanism for precisely and rapidly switching DNA assemblies.

sections.heading: 4.2. Biosensors
sections.text: Zhang has recently developed a gold-based, field-free 3D DNA nanomachine (Figure 13).[99] It composed of four singlestranded DNAs including P1 labeling with electrochemiluminescence (ECL) emitter Ru(bpy)22+ at both ends, P2 labeling with quenchers Alexa Fluor at both ends, and two DNA linkers (A1 and A2). These four strands were self-assembled into 3D DNA nanostructure with DNA nippers as further attachment points via a thermal annealing process in a few minutes. Finally, a thiolmodified capture strand was added to immobilize the nanomachine on the Au substrate. At first, upon Visible light irradiation the 3D DNA nanostructure was at its “OFF” state or in closed configuration, indicated by the very weak ECL signal because of the great distance between the Ru complex and the quenchers. In the presence of the target miRNA-21 from breast cancer cells, the trans conformation of azo incorporated in the DNA nipper region allows the hybridization of miRNA to generate an open state, which resulted in strong ECL signal due to the close proximity between Ru complex and the quenchers. Upon UV irradiation for 10 min, it found that the target miRNA was released from the system and regenerated its off state. This is highly attributed to the trans-to-cis conversion of azo and thus weakening the binding affinity between the targets and the DNAs in nipper regions. This 3D DNA machine is considered as the ultrasensitive detection of miRNA in a single and rapid step. The remote control and photoswitching features allows the system being as a biosensor to reversibly operate without producing any waste.

Kinetin, ATP and the DNA strand were critical for swarming or solitary of MTs. The azo-modified DNAs were used as linkers between the microtubules. The swarm formation and deformation could be controlled by sequential UV and visible light irradiation. Under visible light irradiation, azo molecules favored trans configuration for DNA hybridization, resulting in translational swarming of DNAconjugated MTs. Afterward, these rigid MTs were irradiated with UV light, azo molecules would adapt the cis-conformation and deform the DNA hybridization, leading to the dissociation of swarm into flexible MTs. They showed that the reversibility of the MTs could be performed up to three cycles. Importantly, irradiation of flexible MTs with UV light would generate swarm with circular movement. Therefore, this work significantly demonstrated the photoisomerization of azo molecules on the DNA linkers enables reversible switching between swarming and solitary behaviors in response to the sequential UV and Visible light irradiation.

sections.heading: 4.4. Cargo Loading and Release
sections.text:
Tan and his co-workers have demonstrated photocontrolled drug release from a mesoporous silica nanocapsule, which was functionalized with many short DNA linkers at their pores (Figure 15A).[101] Anticancer drug such as doxorubicin is small enough to be trapped into those pores in the silica nanocapsule azobenzene. In the presence of azo-modified staple DNA strands under visible light irradiation, these azo molecules were in their trans state and would allow the staple strand to hybridize to its complementary DNA linkers, resulting in closing of the pores and preventing of drug leakage. Upon UV light irradiation, the staple DNA strands would dissociate from the linkers to open the pore, leading
to the release of drug from the silica nanocarrier. This silica system showed effective light-mediated release of drug from the pores for chemotherapy in human acute lymphoblastic leukemic CEM and human lung adenocarcinoma A549 cells. His group and Schneider’s also further produced a photoresponsive hydrogel for controllable release of drugs with azobenzene approach.[102,103]
Additionally, Sugiyama’s group applied the photoisomerization of azobenzene moiety and toehold strand displacement reaction to finely control the closing and opening of a square bipyramid DNA nanocapsule and the selective encapsulation and release of a gold nanoparticles.[104] In the left-handed side, the two hemispheres were linked by a single-stranded DNA one side of the two DNA pyramids were permanently connected while the rest of three edges were linked by complementary azomodified DNA strands. Upon UV light irradiation, the cis-form azo disrupted the duplex hybridization and then the two linking strands were dissociated, resulting in opening of the nanocapsule. Meanwhile, DNA-conjugated AuNPs were added for active encapsulation via DNA hybridization inside the lower pyramid. Afterward, the capsule could be closed when visible light was applied to the system. Subsequent irradiation of UV light and addition of an eraser DNA strand, the nanocapsule opened again and the encapsulated cargos could be released by strand displacement strategy (Figure 15B). This open/close DNA system for capture and release of materials would allow us to trap some active molecular payloads and protected them during the entire delivery process. Finally, they can be precisely released in the particular sites of interested in response to light irradiation.
Recently, Li et al. also reported the design of azo-incorporated DNA-based nanochannels for regulating molecular transport. The inner wall of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) channel was modified with azo-functionalized DNA strands (Figure 15C).[105] Under visible light irradiation, azo molecules changed into trans form and then hairpin DNA structures was formed in which the diameter of the inner channel was increased. Subsequently, the azo molecules returned to their cis form and the DNA strands

With the irradiation of UV light in this DNA gel system, it would allow the drug release by DNA melting, resulting in synergistic thermo– chemo combination cancer therapy.[109] All these samples show that photoresponsive DNA nanomaterials could be widely utilized in the smart drug delivery process.

One-photon cleavable molecule 1-(2-nitrophenyl)-ethyl derivative (2-NP) and two-photon cleavable molecule 4-nitro-4′-phenoxy-1,1′-biphenyl (4-NB), two different fluorophores (Cy3 and FAM) and fluorescence quenchers were simultaneously introduced to the system as shown in Figure 16A. At the initial state without any light input, fluorescence quenching is observed because the two fluorophores are in close proximity to the fluorescence quenchers. This leads to a false operating output signal of 0. In the presence of NIR irradiation, the 4-NB molecule was cleaved selectively and the 8-base S2a was unhybridized to DNA device at room temperature as the melting temperature of S2a is about 17 °C. This resulted in the restoration of FAM fluorescence (output) upon excitation. In contrast, when UV irradiation is applied, the 2-NP molecules was cleaved and thus caused a separation of the 8-base S1a from the fluorescence quenchers as the melting temperature of S1a is about 13.5 °C. Adding the corresponding amount of S1 and S2 strands to the logic gate system at (1,1) would simply displace the two shorter S1b and S2b strands. This would result in resetting the OR DNA logic gate to its original state at (0,0). sections.heading: 4.6. Fabrication and Photolithography
sections.text:
With the help of photoresponsive moieties, the modified surface could be masked or unmasked by light. Eritja’s group has first modified the surface of silicon substrates with numerous amino functional groups for subsequent covalent conjugation of an intramolecular DNA oligonucleotides hairpin (Figure 17A).[110] A UV cleavable molecule, e.g., o-nitrobenzyl group was incorporated to the middle part of the hairpin loop. Under UV light irradiation, the loop would be cleaved thus resulting in DNA oligonucleotide in its single-stranded form. This unhybridized DNA region can be selectively recognized by its complementary DNA strand for further immobilization of new nanomaterials at specific sites or with designed patterns. In this work, UV photolithography was performed using a mask aligner. For example, gold and rhodamine could be effectively
patterned on the substrate at the unmasking region after photoirradiation. With this technique, conditional nanofabrication could be done in a more precise and accurate manner.
Additionally, the photopatterning could be conducted in a reversible way. Huang has simply made use of the photocleavage of 2-nitrobenzyl modified DNA strand as linker for DNA photolithography.[111] Sequence-designed DNA strands were conjugated on the gold substrate and hybridized with their complementary photocleavable DNA strands (LSs). After conducting photomasking, the fluorophore-labeled linking strands (RSs) was then hybridized with LSs, giving rise to the designed patterns. Patterns with two different colors on the substrate can also be created by adding two different fluorophore-labeled RS strands (Figure 17B). In their design, to erase the lithography, UV irradiation could be conducted without photomasking as shown in step (6), then all LS and/or RS strands would be cleaved from the surface. Strand displacement of LS strand on the substrate is highly possible in order to regenerate the original surface for further photolithography. By combing the toehold-mediated strand displacement reaction with DNA photolithography, the precise fabrication of various complex DNA patterns on a single chip surface is highly feasible. Additionally, this developed DNA photolithography is erasable in which allows for repeated paintings on the same chip.
The most recent DNA photolithography utilized o-nitrobenzylphosphate ester, which could be photocleaved by UV and NIR light for surface patterning of single microparticles. By introducing some foreign compounds with light sensitive properties, the behavior of the living bodies could be controlled optically. With these well-established techniques, photoregulating gene expression with an antisense strategy in vitro or in vivo is highly possible.
In Chen’s work, light-driven substrate channeling platform in an enzyme cascade was investigated on a DNA origami. DNA origami allows the enzyme, substrate, and the movable arm located at precise position (Figure 18A).[116] This model made use of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6pDH) and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) as the enzyme cascade, and the cofactor was nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). If the cofactor was channeling between the two cascades, glucose-6-phosphate would be oxidized by G6pDH and then followed by reduction of NAD+ to generate NADH. NADH was then used by LDH to reduce pyruvate to lactate. NAD+ would be regenerated for the continuous cascade reaction. Both the anchor and HJ DNA strand were incorporated with azobenzene. Under visible light irradiation, the cascade reaction would stop as anchor strand and the HJ sequence were hybridized together to inhibit the substrate channeling. Once the UV light was applied, the HJ and anchor strands were dissociated and the swing arm could be released and bring the NAD+ close proximity between the two enzyme cascades for substrate channeling. With this light-driven substrate channeling approach, it could be simply applied in synthetic biology and biomedicine sectors such as optogenetics. sections.heading: 4.8. Post Transcription Altering
sections.text: Light is orthogonal to many biological processes and can be simply utilized as a trigger to remove photocaging moieties as mentioned previously. Recently, Rentmeister’s group synthesized a novel class of S-adenosyl-ʟ-methionine (AdoMet) derivatives consisting of photocaging (PC) groups including ONB, p-nitrobenzyl (PNB), 4-acetyl-2-nitrobenzyl (ANB), and 2-anthraquinonyl-resides (ANT) for enzymatic transfer by a DNA methyltransferases (MTases).[119] They found that all four PC groups were effectively transferred from AdoPC to double-stranded DNA (Figure 19) but only the ONB- and ANB-group could be efficiently removed from the N6 position of adenosine nucleobase on DNA strand upon UV 365 nm irradiation. The advantages of using UV caging groups are to block the enzymatic cleavage of plasmid DNAs. These target DNA strands would be uncaged and accessible to restriction enzymes once the caging groups were removed by UV light. Their work could provide a simple strategy to alter bioactive macromolecules reversibly and postsynthetically and thus has provided a novel method of spatial and temporal control of many biological processes at the levels of gene expression.

sections.heading: 5. Summary and Outlook
sections.text:
Photoresponsive DNA nanomaterials represent a new class of remarkable functional materials for biotechnological application
and materials science. By adjusting the irradiation wavelength, light intensity and exposure time, various photocontrolled DNA-based systems can be reversibly or irreversibly regulated in respect of their size, shape, conformation, movement, and dissociation/association. Typical four light-controlled switching approaches can be readily utilized to oligonucleotides with different structures, sequences, and functions by simply conjugating photoresponsive molecules into the DNA strands using standard solid-phase synthesis on an automated DNA synthesizer via cyanoethylphosphoramidite chemistry. Significant in vitro studies have strongly indicated the advantages of using light-responsive DNA assemblies in cargo delivery, biosensing, optogenetic, posttranscription altering, photolithography, logic gates, molecular motors, and switches.
With the significant progress and scientific breakthrough in the development of phototriggered DNA nanomaterials, we are still facing several remarkable challenges. First, to facilitate the versatility of chemical conjugation between oligonucleotide and photoresponsive molecules, a novel series of photocleavable molecules with various functional groups, e.g., N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS) for amino chemistry or alkyne functional group for click chemistry in solution phase is highly necessary. Alkyne readily reacts with azide-functionalized oligonucleotides in the presence of copper (I) to form a stable 1,2,3-triazole bond.[120] With this approach, the photoresponsive molecule could be conjugated on the DNA with a milder condition.
Second, modification of oligonucleotides with azobenzene molecules is the most direct way to achieve photoresponsiveness because of its high chemical stability and photoisomerization efficiency. Although a number of groups have successfully designed and synthesized some azobenzene derivatives to ameliorate the poor thermal stability of azobenzene in its cis-form and relatively low photoregulation ability.[58,121–125] Nevertheless, the low trans-to-cis conversion efficiency in the DNA duplex at room temperature is still a big problem, which highly limits its practical applications in biology and nanotechnology. Generally, only ≈30% azobenzene molecules were photoisomerized to cisconformation in a 35-mer DNA duplex at 37 °C.[126] Liang et al. also reported that the azobenzene-functionalized DNA tweezers could only work well at ≈50 °C.[63] Therefore, it is highly necessary to generate a highly efficient photoisomerizable azobenzene-anchored DNA strand to satisfy the photocontrolled actuations at room temperature. Several research groups have found that azobenzene linked with ether bonds usually eliminate the low trans-to-cis conversion efficiency penalty.[127–129] Recently, Liang’s group successfully demonstrated the use of glycerol linker to integrate azobenzene into DNA strand with great improvements in its operation efficiency at room temperature.[130] Their work would result in an energysafe, convenient, and economical-friendly operation process.
Third, the development of light-driven directed movement of azobenzene-functionalized DNA nanomaterials in an aqueous solution is highly attractive. Indeed, the directional control of the motion of these DNA-based nanomaterials is not an easy task and still remains a great challenge. It has been found that surface relief gratings of azo-polymer films have been achieved under light intensity gradients, taking advantage of mass transport toward the dark regions where photoisomerization

is minimized.[131] Recently, Brasselet’s group also reported the use of azobenzene-coated polymeric nanoparticles as phototriggered propellers by converting photo energy to mechanical work with optical control.[132] They showed that these nanoparticles could be driven over 10 µm by adjusting the light intensity gradients in the plane. Based on these studies, we strongly believe that this phenomenon can be used to achieve the directionally controlled motion of 3D DNA nanotubes in an aqueous medium. Ideally, tubular DNA nanotubes can specifically be designed to circumvent Brownian motion using the photoinduced isomerization of attached motor molecules such as azobenzene to evoke their motion toward the dark areas of the adjusted illumination. In principle, these tubular DNAbased materials take advantage of Brownian motion to investigate the bright areas of the samples efficiently and thus give rise to controlled motion.
Furthermore, most of these reported photoresponsive DNA nanosystems are just proof-of concept studies for biological studies. Investigation of light-triggered DNA nanomaterials in in vivo platforms or stepped into the preclinical stage still remain a big gap. Liang’s group demonstrated the use of DNA origami structures loaded with intercalatedphotosensitizer 3,6-bis[2-(1-methylpyridinium) ethynyl]-9-pentyl-carbazole diiodide (BMEPC) for efficient killing of cancer cells via photodynamic therapy.[133] This kind of disease therapy is highly attributed to the generation of destructive reactive oxygen species (ROSs) from BMEPC in which these ROSs kill the target cells selectively. Even though they claimed that their work held great promise for clinical application because this photosensitizer could simultaneously be activated by NIR light. There are still significant difficulties to impede their transition from the bench to the bedside. For example, the immunogenicity effects of these photoresponsive DNA-based systems have to be fully studied and addressed in the coming decades. Although some o-nitrobenzyl photolabile protecting moieties exhibited redshifted in their UV–vis absorption maxima, their two-photon uncaging cross section values were still remain quite low (<0.1 GM), which is insufficient for use in biological studies.[134,135] Kramer and co-workers recently reported that the nitrophenyl core such as 2-(4′-(bis(carboxymethyl)amino)-4-nitro-[1,1′biphenyl]-3-yl)propan-1-ol (CANBP) and 2-(4′-(bis((2-methoxyethoxy)ethyl)amino)-4-nitro-[1,1′-biphenyl]-3-yl)pro-pan-1-ol (EANBP) exhibited much higher TPA among the best described so far.[136] Interestingly, it is found that the replacement of the alkoxy group (OMe) by a dialkyl (e.g., carboxylmethyl or 2-(2-methoxylethoxyl)ethyl) amino group in the donor–acceptor biphenyl 2-(o-nitrophenyl)propyl series, e.g., PMNB give rise to a red-shifted absorption maxima but with no remarkable effect on the kinetics and efficiency of its photolytic reaction. Importantly, the substitution also dramatically increased the two-photon sensitivity of these photoremovable groups, resulting in an unprecedented two-photon uncaging action cross-section up to 11 GM at λ = 800 nm. Such high two-photon uncaging efficiency would allow us to further explore the two-photon-triggered release of biological molecules with the classical lasers integrated in TP excited microscopy. This would avoid the use of high intensity amplified pulsed laser. Moreover, the modification of the functional side chains also opens the door for enhancing the aqueous solubility of these photolabile molecules.
